data.title: Love this place
data.text: They serve flights of wine while you watch a classic film on the big screen. The food is home cooked and delicious. Little portions, but very yummy. The owner is warm, friendly and very attentive. It's conveniently located in Theater Square. Come here before the movies. Or come here after the movies. But if you like fine wine, then definitely come here.

data.title: Looking for a place to relax, laugh and maybe fall in love?
data.text: LDV is always my go to place… with guests, local friends or my sweetie of 28 years…..or just me alone. Thanks S

data.title: Very nice for couples
data.text: My wife and I were headed to the theatre near by and stopped on for a glass of wine and a cheese tray. Well, presented as well as a great wine selection. Outdoor seating in the quad area with a fountain nearby. Very nice setting for couples and friends.

data.title: Always tasty food to accompany great wine and hospitality
data.text: We have been visiting La Dolce Vita since their opening many years ago and consistently return for any combination of delicious wine, food, and amicable staff. The salads are always very good and watch out for some delicious vegetarian soup specials whipped up by Sahar's family.

data.title: A place to gather and enjoy good wine and some snacks
data.text:
This wine bar/lounge is in the theater district of Petaluma. It is right across the street from the movie theater. It would be a nice place to go before or after a movie. 
They have wines from all over the US and Europe. My husband enjoyed a flight of exotic white wines, I enjoyed a fight of Rhone red wines. They have numerous flight options that range in price from $17 to $29 a flight. Each flight includes three wines; each pour is 3 ounces. 
The food menu is limited. We had a plate of 3 cheeses that was served with bread, crackers, almonds, and apples. The price for this plate is $15.00. We also had their roasted potatoes ($8.00) that were spiced and served with a ketchup-style dipping sauce and a mustard dipping sauce. In addition we enjoyed a pear, caramelized onion, goat cheese, and bacon pizza. The pizza ($13.00) is the size of a large dinner plate. Everything was delicious and substantial. We could not eat it all! We took home half the pizza and half the roasted potatoes. I enjoyed them for my lunch the next day.
La Dolce Vita Wine Lounge also shows movies on the wall above the bar. The sound is off; but, the dialogue is screened in print as the movie plays. This way, people can enjoy conversation without having to talk over the sound of the movie; and, people who want to enjoy the movie don't have to strain to hear the dialogue.
Overall, this is a nice place to go to meet friends, to go as a couple, to go with co-workers to enjoy their happy hour. My husband and I will definitely go back -- in fact, we plan to go back the next time we go see a movie. We will go after the movie to enjoy another wine flight and to try another one of their pizzas.

data.title: Good wine, friendly and knowledgeable staff
data.text: We were impressed by our waiters knowledge of the wines that we had questions about. We were not sure which bottle we wanted so he let us try a small taste of the ones we were curious about. We settled with a malbec and Argentina, which was excellent. My friend got an appetizer plate of salami cheese and olives, which she loved. I look forward to going back.

data.title: Overpriced for amount of food given
data.text: We were looking forward to catching up with a friend we haven't seen for ages. We ordered a few platters (cheese and cured meets) just for nibbles. Staff were very friendly and regularly checked in on us. Food was expensive for the little amount that was served. We left hungry and in search of dinner.

data.title: Love this place!
data.text: Great little wine bar that has an edgy sexy upscale feel.  The owner is delightful and she is usually there with suggestions and a smile. They have great food there, too, but I feel you go there to try the wine first.  Good meeting place for after work or going to the cinema.

data.title: Much more than just a wine lounge
data.text: Really good food and a good number of local beers in addition to the fantastic wine selection. We thought this was just a wine bar and were very pleasantly surprised when we stopped in for a drink before a movie and saw that they had a full menu. The food is excellent and pairs well with the wine and beer.

data.title: Wonderful!
data.text: We dropped in without any knowledge of the place and were pleasantly surprised! Great food, great wine recommendations and great service! Will probably go again tomorrow!

data.title: Chic oasis in downtown Petaluma
data.text: Right on Theater Square, perfect for a before-the-show drink, or after, or just a drink without the show, is La Dolce Vita.  Enter into this darkly lit cavern, with tea lights decorating every table, window-side couches, and classic movies projected above the bar, and you enter into a respite from the downtown hub bub. Their wine selection is excellent, the staff knowledgeable, friendly and courteous, and they even offer a flight of wine from hometown Petaluma.  Their snacks are actually light meals, in case you wanted to forego with a heavy dinner elsewhere and have another glass of wine.   They serve in flights, or by the glass.  The owner is always there, and is a lovely woman who knows her wines, good food and how to make her guests always feel welcome. Eat here, drink here, relax here. Enjoy.

data.title: Comfort and comfort food
data.text: I hate bars. I have meet girl friends at the wine lounge quite a few times and loved how comfortable I felt….as if I were at a friend's house.  I am in a movie group-like a book club except with movies. As the Lounge is so close to Petaluma Cinemas, we decided to go there for dinner as well as our after movie discussion stop. I was very surprised at the extensive dinner menu and how yummy everyone's meal was. The survive was great.

data.title: Warm and inviting atmosphere with a friendly staff, great service, delicious food
data.text: After an unpleasant 10 minutes at a wine bar down the street we entered La Dolce Vita.  We were immediately welcomed and given menus.  We were delighted with the specials, yummy butternut squash pizza and a salad of persimmons and pommegranets and pecans.  We enjoyed a wine flight and the very warm and cozy atmosphere.

data.title: Great Wine Bar
data.text: This wine bar has the best selection of wines and food pairings that I have ever seen.  The owner and staff are extremely knowledgeable and will make sure that you have a wonderful experience.  Don't leave Petaluma without a visit to La Dolce Vita!

data.title: Living La Vita Dolce
data.text:
This is a charming wine lounge located in downtown Petaluma across the street from Boulevard Cinemas. It is a great place to have a glass of wine to concentrate your mind before a serious movie, and have a light meal, or to have another glass of wine or bubbly to unwind after an action thriller, sob story or musical and top off the evening with a dessert. In keeping with its location in Theatre Square, La Dolce Vita Wine Lounge shows movies on the wall behind the bar from the owner’s collection of classic DVDs, and hosts an Oscar Night. 

The wine menu is organized into groups called flights. Recent titles are Rhone Rangers, Sauvignon Blanc, Pinot Noir (more on that in a moment), Zinfandel, Cabernet Sauvignon, Bordeaux Varietals and Around the World Reds. Each flight offers a three-ounce taste. If you like something, you can order a glass, half bottle, full bottle served, or a retail bottle to go. The menu gives tasting notes.  For example, Las Mercedes Estate Carmenere 2011 from Maule Valley, Chile: “Expressive and juicy flavors of dense plum, earth, espresso and leather lead to a silky finish.” Note that the wine list changes frequently. As of my recent visit, flights are $15-$19. 

The Pinot Noir flight currently includes Luli 2011 from Santa Lucia Highlands, Folk Machine Westward Expansion 2011 from Potter Valley and Kokumi 2010 from Sonoma Coast.  Notes for the latter are: “Intense fruit aromas of sweet cherry, plum and currants, with notes of violets, herbs de Provence and spice on the velvety finish. Just 120 cases produced.”

Owner Sahar Gharai was inspired to launch this business in 2007 after studying in a wine program in Italy near Florence. There, she visited several wine cafés and was charmed by the atmosphere where wine was “the star.” The outdoor seating area suggests this European sidewalk café influence. She gave interior design architect Rudabeh Pakravan a general direction—to make it modern and also warm. So instead of industrial chic, it features paneling and a ceiling (no exposed pipes and ducts) and luxurious lounge seating. The result is a place where patrons can feel comfortable enjoying wine and chatting for hours. I particularly like to admire the “wine wall” which houses bottles in mounted racks in the lounge area. The high windows encourage people-watching.

Food Menu: One adventurous night, I ordered the Bacon, Roasted Pear, Caramelized Onion and Goat Cheese Pizza. I say adventurous because it took me a long time to accept putting pineapple on pizza Hawaiian style; forgive me, I was born in New York. The onion flavor did not overpower the rest. The pairing suggestion was for a Pinot Grigio but I enjoyed it with a flight of international reds. I also recommend the Roasted Almonds ($4), the Marinated Olives ($4) and Piatti di Salumi ($11), a platter of sliced Italian Meats, Dubliner Cheese and Olives. For a lingering visit try the cheese plates which offer three selections for $12 or seven for $25. Choices include Mt Tam Cow Cheese from Cowgirl Creamery, and others from the U.S., Spain and Ireland, all served with French bread, apples and almonds.

Desserts include Chocolate Soufflé Cake, Limoncello Cake, Cheesecake and Tiramisu ($7-8). My favorite perk-up to finish a meal is the Caffe Glace: Vanilla Bean Gelato topped with coffee and whipped cream. 

I have visited about a dozen times over the last few years, including two Oscar nights which have the awards showing on the screen behind the bar, a red carpet, trivia contests, and awards for customers, who are encouraged to dress up or in character. Some members of the “Petaluminati” watch the Academy Awards on the big screen theater and then join the “after-party” at LDV, or just stay there for the whole show.

This hospitality experience has a lot going for it: location, concept, décor, product, and service. It also has two X factors: atmosphere and charm. The owner and staff enjoy answering questions and will try to determine your taste to recommend something you might like. They enjoy sharing their enthusiasm. I asked Sahar what are the wines to watch in the near future. She is excited about the California Pinot Noir 2012 vintage, especially Napa and Sonoma, and wines from Chile.

LDV also provides one detail very well. When you get your flight, each glass is labeled. In a convivial conversation it is easy to forget which wine is which, so the label is a simple but thoughtful gesture.

Great place for a first date or an anniversary. Romantic, urbane, joyous. There is a loyal group of regulars who welcome newcomers. Like other newer wine lounges, La Dolce Vita encourages exploration and celebration to overcome the reputation wine has that intimidates those new to wine tasting. You don’t have to be an expert, just be curious, and even the experts like to be surprised by a new region or producer. My suggestion: offer a flight of wines from New Zealand, where The Hobbit and Lord of the Rings were filmed, and call it the Frodo Flight!

data.title: Incredible atmosphere, great food and wine, wonderful service!
data.text: We stopped in for a tasting and thoroughly enjoyed the food and wine!  Mercury cellars was at the restaurant pouring wine and providing education about their amazing blends. We ordered the crostini sampler and dessert and were very satisfied with both.

data.title: Nice place to meet with Friend over a glass of wine
data.text: Great place to sit down and relax with friends. Nice wine selection and they show old movies inside. Outside seating for a nice afternoon in the theater district

data.title: A quick stop for a glass of wine turns into a a long stop.
data.text: This was the second time we have been to LDV. What starts out as a quick stop before dinner, turns into a long evening and a great time.  The Owner and her staff are helpful and friendly, answering all the questions we have about the wine selections offering suggestions based on our preferences.  What a marvelous place to just sit and relax, enjoying friends, good wine and great food. We never left and had a dinner of several different Tapas- ooh soo good.  Will be back, soon.

data.title: Petaluma Favorite
data.text: We have been regulars here for quite some time.  The people are very friendly, and will help with wine selections if you're venturing into unfamiliar territory giving you a taste prior to committing to a bottle/glass.  The pear/bacon pizza is awesome!  Get TWO of them (I can eat a whole one by myself -- ashamedly).  The classic movies shown is also a lot of fun.  The atmosphere is quiet enough to allow for intimacy, but also there is a more 'party' section if that is what your occasion is calling for.

data.title: City food and wine standards with small town friendliness
data.text:
While visiting family in picturesque Sonoma Co. we were taken to a superb tapas/wine bar.
My daughter knew my husband and I enjoy good wine and food and would accept no substitutes. She introduced us to her favorite place to eat in Petaluma and her taste was right on. Tucked back in a little square we probably would never have found it on our own. Upon entering we were greeted  and invited to choose any seat we wanted. The seating ranged from intimate small tables w/high bar stools to seats at the wooden counter that faced the square, also small tables for 4s that could be arranged for larger groups. There were comfy sofas for groups to gather and sip wine and an outdoor patio to dine on warmer days.

Enough about the casual yet elegant atmosphere. There was a lengthy wine menu of wines by the glass, half liter or bottle to choose from. Wines from Sonoma and Napa, of course, but an equal selection from regions worldwide, The staff was very knowledgeable and happy to help you pick one that would suit your palette.

But ahhh, the food. La Dolce Vita is a small family business, with owner Sahar providing the wine knowledge and mom and dad cooking in the kitchen. Her mom makes a variety of unique hummus and tasty pita chips to accompany them. They offer fabulous bruschettas, including one topped with mushrooms that is divine.  The flatbread  pizzas they serve are also fabulous and come in interesting combinations. Don't miss the carmelized onion with pear and pancetta. It's to die for. A variety of fresh local salads  round out the meal. Don't forget to try desserts; they too are delicious.

This is one of my favorite places to eat in Petaluma and I can't wait to return on my next trip.
